anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated April 28, 1953, of the Madras High Court

The legal position is well settled that if in fact at the date of acquisition of a particular property the joint family had sufficient nucleus for acquiring it, the property In the name of any member of the joint family should be presumed to be acquired from out of family funds and so to form part of the joint family property, unless the companytrary is shown.  Vide Amritlal Sen ors., v. Surath Lal Sen others 1  Appalaswami v. Suryanarayanamurthy others 2 .

concepts.interpretation: Presumption that property acquired in name of joint family member is joint family property if joint family had sufficient nucleus at time of acquisition, even if funds advanced by Karta who has personal funds; presumption rebutted if no sufficient nucleus exists, as determined by detailed calculation of family income and expenditure.

concepts.unlisted_description: Rebuttable presumption that acquisitions by joint family members using family nucleus funds belong to joint family

anchor.surface_text: While admitting the legal position that in the absence of any evidence of fraud or misappropriation the Karta cannot be called upon to account for the past transactions, learned Counsel stresses the responsibility of the Karta to establish what are the assets available for partition.

concepts.interpretation: Karta not liable to account for past transactions absent fraud, but must disclose existing divisible assets; court must inquire into actual assets at partition time, not accept Karta's statement alone.

concepts.unlisted_description: Limits on Karta's accounting duty in joint family partition to current assets absent misconduct

issues.text: The question whether the joint family had at the time of each of these acquisitions sufficient nucleus from which the acquisitions could have been made

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the joint family had at the time of each of these acquisitions sufficient nucleus from which the acquisitions could have been made is therefore of great importance. On a consideration of the evidence, as discussed below, we have come to the conclusion that it does not appear that the joint family had at the date of the acquisitions made in the names of the first defendants wife.

issues.text: whether the properties purchased in the name of the first defendants wife, his son, and his grandson subsequent to 1930 were acquired with joint family funds under the nucleus presumption

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel submitted that the High Court did not record any clear conclusion that at the date of the acquisition of these properties the joint family had not a sufficient nucleus for acquiring these. He argued that the acquisitions in the name of the first defendants wife was admittedly with funds advanced by the first defendant himself and if at the date of the acquisition in her name the joint family had sufficient nucleus for acquiring them, the presumption would be that they were acquired with joint family funds notwithstanding the fact that the first defendant may have sufficient funds of his own for the same purpose.

issues.text: the responsibility of the Karta to establish what are the assets available for partition in the absence of evidence of fraud or misappropriation

anchor.surface_text: While admitting the legal position that in the absence of any evidence of fraud or misappropriation the Karta cannot be called upon to account for the past transactions, learned Counsel stresses the responsibility of the Karta to establish what are the assets available for partition. In support of this, the learned Counsel drew our attention to the decision in Parmeshwar Dube v. Gobind Dube.

issues.text: whether there was sufficient joint family nucleus during 1931-1939 for acquisitions in Schedules B, B1, C, C1, C2, D and related properties

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding therefore on the basis on which there is no longer any dispute, that the D Schedule lands were acquired out of the family funds, it appears clear that the joint family did not possess sufficient nucleus for making any of the other purchases made during this period, viz., the properties mentioned in Schedules B and B1 purchased by the document Ex. 125, the properties mentioned in Schedule C1 purchased by the document Ex. B 124, the properties mentioned in Schedule C purchased by Ex. 129, the properties mentioned in the Schedule to the written statement of the second defendant purchased by documents Exhibits B 134 and B 135.

issues.text: whether the first defendant had joint family funds available during 1940-1945 for acquisitions in Schedules C2, B2 Item 1 and Item 5

anchor.surface_text: To decide whether these properties or the properties mentioned in Item 5 of Schedule B2, a house in Vepatthur, of which mortgage was taken in the name of the first defendant himself by Ex. B 192 on the 10th May 1942, formed part of the joint family property, it is necessary to examine what funds, if any, belonging to the joint family were with the first defendant during these years.

issues.text: whether properties purchased in 1945 and 1946 in name of third defendant form part of joint family property

anchor.surface_text: Some of the properties mentioned in Schedule B2 to the plaint were purchased in 1945 and 1946 by Ex. B 127 and B. 128 in the name of the third defendant, Venkatarama. At the time of these acquisitions the third defendant had been karnam of Vepatthur for over 15 years.

arguments.claim: No sufficient joint family nucleus post-1931 for disputed acquisitions

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the joint family had at the time of each of these acquisitions sufficient nucleus from which the acquisitions could have been made is therefore of great importance. On a consideration of the evidence, as discussed below, we have come to the conclusion that it does not appear that the joint family had at the date of the acquisitions made in the names of the first defendants wife.

holdings.text: The legal position is well settled that if in fact at the date of acquisition of a particular property the joint family had sufficient nucleus for acquiring it, the property in the name of any member of the joint family should be presumed to be acquired from out of family funds and so to form part of the joint family property, unless the contrary is shown.

anchor.surface_text: The legal position is well settled that if in fact at the date of acquisition of a particular property the joint family had sufficient nucleus for acquiring it, the property In the name of any member of the joint family should be presumed to be acquired from out of family funds and so to form part of the joint family property, unless the companytrary is shown.  Vide Amritlal Sen ors., v. Surath Lal Sen others 1  Appalaswami v. Suryanarayanamurthy others 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites precedents Amritlal Sen and Appalaswami to affirm settled doctrine of joint family nucleus presumption.

holdings.text: It does not appear that the joint family had at the date of the acquisitions made in the names of the first defendant's wife, his son, and his grandson sufficient nucleus from which these properties could be acquired.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the joint family had at the time of each of these acquisitions sufficient nucleus from which the acquisitions could have been made is therefore of great importance. On a consideration of the evidence, as discussed below, we have come to the conclusion that it does not appear that the joint family had at the date of the acquisitions made in the names of the first defendants wife.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed review of evidence shows no sufficient nucleus post-1931 after accounting for prior acquisitions and expenditures.

holdings.text: The Subordinate Judge's conclusion that a little more than Rs. 14,000 out of the Rs. 15,000 held by the first defendant in 1931 was savings from family funds is not justified by the evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that a little more than Rs. 14,000 - out of this amount was the savings from the family funds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court; evidence of personal earnings from Karnam salary, banana plantations, litigation reward, document fees sufficient for accumulation.

holdings.text: The first defendant had accumulated Rs. 15,000 out of his own earnings by about 1931.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the materials on the record do number justify the Trial Courts view that Ramakrishna companyld number have accumulated a sum of Rs. 15,000/- out of his own income. The mamools which he received as Karnam of Narasingampettai and later on of the bigger village Vepatthur amounted to a companysiderable quan tity of paddy and must have fetched him a goodly income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Personal sources including Karnam mamools, banana plantations, Rs. 2,500 litigation reward, document writing fees credible and sufficient.

holdings.text: The joint family did not possess sufficient nucleus for making any of the purchases in Schedules B, B1, C1, C, properties by Ex. B 134 and B 135 during 1931-1939, except D Schedule lands which were acquired out of family funds.

anchor.surface_text: Proceeding therefore on the basis on which there is no longer any dispute, that the D Schedule lands were acquired out of the family funds, it appears clear that the joint family did not possess sufficient nucleus for making any of the other purchases made during this period, viz., the properties mentioned in Schedules B and B1 purchased by the document Ex. 125, the properties mentioned in Schedule C1 purchased by the document Ex. B 124, the properties mentioned in Schedule C purchased by Ex. 129, the properties mentioned in the Schedule to the written statement of the second defendant purchased by documents Exhibits B 134 and B 135.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income Rs. 16,724 vs. expenditure over Rs. 18,000 creates deficit after D Schedule purchase.

holdings.text: There was no nucleus from the joint family properties which the first defendant could have possibly used in making the acquisitions of properties in Schedule C2, Item 1 of B2, Item 5 of B2 during 1941-1942.

anchor.surface_text: To decide whether these properties or the properties mentioned in Item 5 of Schedule B2, a house in Vepatthur, of which mortgage was taken in the name of the first defendant himself by Ex. B 192 on the 10th May 1942, formed part of the joint family property, it is necessary to examine what funds, if any, belonging to the joint family were with the first defendant during these years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff managed properties 1940-1945 per second defendant's statement and evidence; prior deficit; only ~Rs. 1,500 from D lands insufficient.

holdings.text: Properties purchased in 1945 and 1946 in the name of the third defendant mentioned in Schedule B2 did not form part of the joint family property.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the properties mentioned in Schedule B2 to the plaint were purchased in 1945 and 1946 by Ex. B 127 and B. 128 in the name of the third defendant, Venkatarama. At the time of these acquisitions the third defendant had been karnam of Vepatthur for over 15 years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Third defendant had own earnings as Karnam for 15+ years; no evidence of sufficient family nucleus with first defendant post-1945.

holdings.text: In the absence of fraud or other improper conduct the Karta is not liable to account for past transactions beyond disclosing the existing state of divisible property, but the court must inquire into actual assets; application depends on facts and circumstances of each case.

anchor.surface_text: While admitting the legal position that in the absence of any evidence of fraud or misappropriation the Karta cannot be called upon to account for the past transactions, learned Counsel stresses the responsibility of the Karta to establish what are the assets available for partition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Parmeshwar Dube precedent; no dispute on proposition, but fact-specific application.

precedents.case_name: Amritlal Sen v Surath Lal Sen
precedents.cited_proposition: if in fact at the date of acquisition of a particular property the joint family had sufficient nucleus for acquiring it, the property in the name of any member of the joint family should be presumed to be acquired from out of family funds and so to form part of the joint family property, unless the contrary is shown

anchor.surface_text: Appalaswami v. Suryanarayanamurthy others 2 . In the case before us, it is number disputed that the acquisi-

precedents.cited_proposition: if in fact at the date of acquisition of a particular property the joint family had sufficient nucleus for acquiring it, the property in the name of any member of the joint family should be presumed to be acquired from out of family funds and so to form part of the joint family property, unless the contrary is shown

anchor.surface_text: Parmeshwar Dube v. Gobind Dube 1 . That case laid down the rule that in the absence of fraud or other improper

precedents.cited_proposition: in the absence of fraud or other improper conduct the only account the Karta of a joint family is liable for is to the existing state of the property divisible but that this did not mean that the parties were bound to accept the statement of the Karta as to what the property consisted of and an enquiry should be directed by the court in a manner usually adopted to discover what in fact the property consisted of at the date of the partition

anchor.surface_text: The High Courts conclusion as regards these properties that they did not form part of the joint family properties and are therefore not liable to partition in the present suit is therefore clearly correct.

outcome.relief_summary: Upholding High Court; only Schedules A and D properties are joint family properties liable for partition; other acquisitions not from joint family nucleus; no liability for past accounts beyond existing assets with enquiry into current state.
directions: First defendant to account for income from joint family properties (Schedules A and D) from 12th December 1946
Enquiry into existing state of divisible property
